articles.headline: $28,000 a Night: Hotels Race to Attract Superrich Clientele
articles.snippet: Hotels are competing with one another to create luxury suites for the extremely wealthy, who are willing to pay five-figure nightly rates.
articles.abstract: Hotels are competing with one another to create luxury suites for the extremely wealthy, who are willing to pay five-figure nightly rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: In most hotels, luxury is measured by the thread count of the linens (minimum 400, please) or the brand of the bathroom toiletries. But for those at the highest end of the market, where the only restraint on consumption is how conspicuous they want to be, a race to the top has broken out, with hotels outdoing one another to serve this tiny, if highly visible, niche.

articles.headline: Texas Company, Alone in U.S., Cashes In on Nuclear Waste
articles.snippet: Waste Control Specialists is the only company that will dispose of some categories of low-level waste for 95 nuclear reactors in 29 states.
articles.abstract: Waste Control Specialists is the only company that will dispose of some categories of low-level waste for 95 nuclear reactors in 29 states.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANDREWS, Tex. — Standing at the lip of what might be America’s most valuable hole in the ground, Rodney A. Baltzer cataloged the features that he said would isolate the radioactive waste to be buried here for thousands of years.

articles.headline: A Popular Chinese Social Networking App Blazes Its Own Path
articles.snippet: Weixin, a fast-growing app from the Chinese Internet company Tencent, is no mere copy of any existing service, and its success may thwart Facebook’s ambitions in China.
articles.abstract: Weixin, a fast-growing app from the Chinese Internet company Tencent, is no mere copy of any existing service, and its success may thwart Facebook’s ambitions in China.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Every half-hour or so, Jenny Zhao, young and wired, unlocks her iPhone 5 to connect with friends using Weixin, China’s wildly popular social messaging app.

articles.headline: Boston Fed’s Latest Role: Community Organizer
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve Bank of Boston funneled $1.8 million from outside donors to help turn around some of the Massachusetts’ most depressed midsize cities.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve Bank of Boston funneled $1.8 million from outside donors to help turn around some of the Massachusetts’ most depressed midsize cities.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Economists do not tend to be social activists. And that is especially true if they work for the Federal Reserve, let alone run one of its 12 regional banks.

articles.headline: Demand Grows for Hogs That Are Raised Humanely Outdoors
articles.snippet: Some farmers are raising their pigs more humanely in wide open spaces, instead of tight quarters, and selling them to restaurants and grocers increasingly interested in how animals are treated.
articles.abstract: Some farmers are raising their pigs more humanely in wide open spaces, instead of tight quarters, and selling them to restaurants and grocers increasingly interested in how animals are treated.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHUSHAN, N.Y. — Turn down the road to Flying Pigs Farm here, and two or three of Michael Yezzi’s pigs are probably standing in the middle of it.

articles.headline: Notable in Their Absence From Davos
articles.snippet: The leaders of some of the largest and most transformative companies are demonstrating, with their absence, the difficulty of convening a global conversation with all the main stakeholders, writes Andrew Ross Sorkin.
articles.abstract: The leaders of some of the largest and most transformative companies are demonstrating, with their absence, the difficulty of convening a global conversation with all the main stakeholders, writes Andrew Ross Sorkin.
articles.lead_paragraph: The annual parade of boldface names at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, is always striking. This year’s attendees at the meeting, which begins Wednesday, will include Japan’s prime minister, Shinzo Abe; the billionaire Bill Gates; JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive, Jamie Dimon; and the movie star-philanthropist Matt Damon.

articles.headline: Hollande’s Romances Turn Into a Political Spectacle in France
articles.snippet: François Hollande once vowed to be on his most exemplary behavior as president of France. But an affair has exposed a more politically calculating side and threatens to undercut his economic agenda.
articles.abstract: François Hollande once vowed to be on his most exemplary behavior as president of France. But an affair has exposed a more politically calculating side and threatens to undercut his economic agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — As a candidate for the French presidency in 2012, François Hollande promised to be more boring spouse than flamboyant seducer.
articles.byline: By Elaine Sciolino, Alissa J. Rubin and Maïa de la Baume

articles.headline: Parties Seize on Abortion Issues in Midterm Race
articles.snippet: Abortion is becoming an unexpectedly animating issue in the 2014 midterm races, with Republicans using it to stoke enthusiasm among core supporters and Democrats looking to rally female voters.
articles.abstract: Abortion is becoming an unexpectedly animating issue in the 2014 midterm races, with Republicans using it to stoke enthusiasm among core supporters and Democrats looking to rally female voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Republican National Committee gathers for its winter meeting here on Wednesday, the action will start a few hours late to accommodate anyone who wants to stop first at the March for Life, the annual anti-abortion demonstration on the National Mall. And if they need a lift to the meeting afterward, they can hop on a free shuttle, courtesy of the Republican Party.

articles.headline: You Don’t Have to Be Jewish to Love a Kosher Prison Meal
articles.snippet: Florida is under a court order to begin serving kosher food to eligible inmates, alarming officials who report a surge in prisoners, many of them gentiles, interested in going kosher.
articles.abstract: Florida is under a court order to begin serving kosher food to eligible inmates, alarming officials who report a surge in prisoners, many of them gentiles, interested in going kosher.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Captive diners know that a good meal is hard to find.
